scope="row" | {{nihongo||入道右大臣集|Nyūdō Udaijin-shū}}<ref name="ishikawa-maedatreasures">{{cite web |url=http://www.ishibi.pref.ishikawa.jp/tayori/2007/tayori_08/tayori_syosai08_1.html |script-title=ja:前田家の名宝 |trans-title=Famous Treasures of the Maeda Clan |publisher=[[Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=2011-05-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722110936/http://www.ishibi.pref.ishikawa.jp/tayori/2007/tayori_08/tayori_syosai08_1.html |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }}</ref> | [[Minamoto no Shunrai]] and [[Fujiwara no Teika]] (pages 6 and 7) | Transcription of poetry anthology by {{nihongo|[[Fujiwara no Yorimune]]|藤原頼宗}} |<span style="display:none">1008</span>[[Heian period]] | {{sort|book|One book bound of 31 pages by fukuro-toji,<ref name="fukuro-toji" group="nb"/> ink on decorative paper with {{nihongo|five-colored design|彩牋|saisen}}}} | <span style="display:none">Tokyo Tokyo Maeda Ikutokukai</span>[[Maeda Ikutokukai]], [[Tokyo]] | [[File:Nyūdō Udaijin shū.jpg|150px]] |}
====Monogatari, Japanese-Chinese poetry, setsuwa==== There are ten National Treasures of six works of Japanese prose and mixed Chinese-Japanese poetry compiled from between the early 9th and the first half of the 13th century. The manuscripts in this list date from between the early 10th to the second half of the 13th century.<ref name="bunkacho"/> The three volume [[Nihon Ryōiki]] was compiled by the private<ref group="nb">As opposed to a publicly recognized and certified priest ordained by the [[ritsuryō]] state.</ref> priest Kyōkai around 822.<ref name="shiraneb-p118">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=118}}</ref><ref name="shiraneb-p117">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=117}}</ref><ref name="keikai-p3"/> It is the oldest collection of Japanese anecdotes or [[folklore|folk stories]] ([[setsuwa]]) which probably came out of an oral tradition.<ref name="shiraneb-p118"/><ref name="keikai-p3">{{Harvnb|Keikai|Nakamura|1996|p=3}}</ref> Combining Buddhism with local folk stories, this work demonstrates [[Karma in Buddhism|karmic]] causality and functioned as a handbook for preaching.<ref name="shiraneb-p118"/><ref name="shiraneb-p117"/><ref name="keikai-p33">{{Harvnb|Keikai|Nakamura|1996|p=33}}</ref> Two<ref group="nb">They are the so called Kōfuku-ji and Shinpuku-ji manuscripts covering the first volume and the second to third volume respectively.</ref> out of four<ref group="nb">The other two manuscripts are the Maeda (vol. 3) and Kōya (fragments of vols. 1 to 3) manuscripts.</ref> extant distinct but incomplete manuscripts have been designated as a National Treasures.<ref name="keikai-p9">{{Harvnb|Keikai|Nakamura|1996|p=9}}</ref>
One of the earliest [[kana]] materials and one of the oldest extant works of Japanese prose fiction is the ''[[Tosa Diary]]'' written by [[Ki no Tsurayuki]] in 935.<ref name="tsurayuki-p5-7">{{Harvnb|Tsurayuki|Porter|2005|pp=5, 7}}</ref><ref name="miner-p20">{{Harvnb|Miner|1969|p=20}}</ref><ref name="frellesvig-p175">{{Harvnb|Frellesvig|2010|p=175}}</ref> It is also the oldest Japanese [[Travel literature|travel diary]], giving an account of a return journey to Kyoto after a four-year term as prefect of [[Tosa Province]].<ref name="tsurayuki-p5">{{Harvnb|Tsurayuki|Porter|2005|p=5}}</ref><ref name="mason-p85">{{Harvnb|Mason|Caiger|1997|p=85}}</ref><ref name="frederic-p516">{{Harvnb|Frédéric|2005|p=516}}</ref> The diary consists of close to 60 poems,<ref group="nb">Poetry is used to express personal feelings.</ref> connected by prose sections that detail the circumstances and the inspiration for the composition of the poems.<ref name="frederic-p594"/><ref name="mccullough-p1670">{{Harvnb|McCullough|1991|pp=16, 70}}</ref><ref name="varley-p62">{{Harvnb|Varley|2000|p=62}}</ref> The work has been valued as a model for composition in the Japanese style.<ref name="aston-p75-76">{{Harvnb|Aston|2001|pp=75–76}}</ref> The original manuscript by Ki no Tsurayuki had been stored at [[Sanjūsangen-dō|Rengeō-in]] palace library, and later was in the possession of [[Ashikaga Yoshimasa]], after which its trace is lost.<ref name="kornicki-p93"/> All surviving manuscripts of the Tosa Diary are copies of this Rengeō-in manuscript.<ref name="kornicki-p94">{{Harvnb|Kornicki|1998|p=94}}</ref> The oldest extant of these, by [[Fujiwara no Teika]], dates to 1235. One year later his son, [[Fujiwara no Tameie]], produced another copy based on the original. Both transcriptions are complete [[facsimile]]s of the original, inclusive of the text, the layout, orthographical usages, and calligraphy.<ref group="nb">Tameie's transcription contains fewer mistakes than Teika's.</ref><ref name="kornicki-p94"/> They have been designated as National Treasures.<ref name="bunkacho"/>
The 984 Sanbō Ekotoba ("The three jewels" or "Tale of the three brothers" or "Notes on the pictures of the three jewels"), was written by [[Minamoto no Tamenori]] in Chinese for the amusement of a young tonsured princess.<ref name="shiveley-p348">{{Harvnb|Shively|McCullough|1999|p=348}}</ref><ref name="frederic-p815">{{Harvnb|Frédéric|2005|p=815}}</ref><ref>The work's title is variously translated as *"Tale of the three brothers": {{Harvnb|Frédéric|2005|p=815}} *"The three jewels": {{Harvnb|Stone|Walter|2008|p=105}} *"Notes on the pictures of the three jewels": {{Harvnb|Iyengar|2006|p=348}}</ref> It is a collection of Buddhist tales and a guide to important Buddhist ceremonies and figures in Japanese Buddhist history.<ref name="stone-p105">{{Harvnb|Stone|Walter|2008|p=105}}</ref><ref name="groner-p274">{{Harvnb|Groner|2002|p=274}}</ref> The designated manuscript from 1273 is known as the Tōji Kanchiin<ref group="nb">Named after the Kanchiin subtemple of [[Tō-ji]].</ref> manuscript and is the second oldest of the Sanbō Ekotoba. It is virtually complete unlike the late Heian period (Tōdaiji-gire) which is a scattered assortment of fragments.<ref name="kamens-p24">{{Harvnb|Kamens|Minamoto|1988|p=24}}</ref>
The cultural interaction between Japan and China is exemplified by the [[Wakan Rōeishū]], a collection of 234 Chinese poems, 353 poems written in Chinese by Japanese poets ([[Kanshi (poetry)|kanshi]]) and 216 [[Waka (poetry)|waka]], all arranged by topic.<ref name="carter-p125">{{Harvnb|Carter|1993|p=125}}</ref><ref name="shiraneb-p286">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=286}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = Smits | first = Ivo | title = Song as Cultural History: Reading Wakan Roeishu (Interpretations) | journal = [[Monumenta Nipponica]] | volume = 55 | year = 2000 | issue = 3 | pages = 399–427 | jstor = 2668298 }}</ref> Compiled in the early 11th century by [[Fujiwara no Kintō]], it was the first and most successful work of this genre.<ref name="kato-p61"/><ref name="shiraneb-p285"/><ref name="shiveley-p428"/> The English title, "Japanese-Chinese Recitation Collection" indicates that the poems in this collection were meant to be sung.<ref name="kato-p61">{{Harvnb|Katō|Sanderson|1997|p=61}}</ref><ref name="shiraneb-p285">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=285}}</ref><ref name="shiveley-p428">{{Harvnb|Shively|McCullough|1999|p=428}}</ref> The Wakan Rōeishū has been valued as a source for poetry recitation, waka composition and for its calligraphy, as it displayed kana and kanji.<ref name="shiraneb-p286"/><ref name="shiraneb-p287">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=287}}</ref> Three manuscripts of the Wakan Rōeishū written on decorated paper have been designated as National Treasures: the two scrolls at the [[Kyoto National Museum]] contain a complete transcription of the work and are a rare and fully developed example of calligraphy on an ''ashide-e''<ref group="nb">A decorative pictorialized style of calligraphy in which characters are disguised in the shape of reeds (''ashi''), streams, rocks, flowers, birds, etc.</ref> ground;<ref name="jaanus-ashide">{{cite web |url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/a/ashide.htm |title=Ashide |publisher= [[Japanese Architecture and Art Net Users System]]|accessdate= 2011-05-04}}</ref> the Konoe edition at Yōmei Bunko is a beautiful example of ''karakami''<ref group="nb">An earth-colored based paper imported from China.</ref> with five-colored design (''saisen'');<ref name="jaanus-karakami">{{cite web |url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/k/karakami.htm |title=Karakami|publisher= [[Japanese Architecture and Art Net Users System]]|accessdate= 2011-05-04}}</ref> and the Ōtagire is written on dyed paper decorated with gold drawings.<ref name="nakata-p139">{{cite book|last=Nakata|first=Yūjirō|title=The art of Japanese calligraphy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m1hQAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=2011-05-04|date=May 1973|publisher=Weatherhill|isbn=978-0-8348-1013-6|page=139}}</ref><ref name="knm-wakansho"/>
The [[Konjaku Monogatarishū]] from ca. 1120 is the most important setsuwa compilation.<ref name="totman-p133">{{Harvnb|Totman|2000|p=133}}</ref><ref name="shiveley-p446">{{Harvnb|Shively|McCullough|1999|p=446}}</ref> It is an anonymous collection of more than 1,000 anecdotes or tales.<ref name="shiraneb-p529">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=529}}</ref><ref name="shiveley-p447">{{Harvnb|Shively|McCullough|1999|p=447}}</ref> About two-thirds of the tales are Buddhist, telling about the spread of Buddhism from India via China to Japan.<ref name="totman-p133"/><ref name="shiraneb-p529"/> As such it is the first world history of Buddhism written in Japanese.<ref name="shiraneb-p529"/> This National Treasure is also known as the Suzuka Manuscript and consists of nine volumes<ref group="nb">Originally the Konjaku Monogatarishū consisted of 31 volumes of which 28 volumes remain today.</ref> covering setsuwa from India (vols. 2 and 5), China (vols. 7, 9, 10) and Japan (vols. 12, 17, 27, 29).<ref name="bunkacho"/><ref name="shiraneb-p529"/> It is considered to be the oldest extant manuscript of the Konjaku Monogatarishū and has served as a source for various later manuscripts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edb.kulib.kyoto-u.ac.jp/exhibit/konjaku/kjaisat.htm |script-title=ja:御挨拶|year=1996 |work=「今昔物語集」への招待 (Invitation to the Konjaku Monogatarishū) |publisher=[[Kyoto University]] |language=Japanese |trans-title=Greeting|accessdate= 2011-05-02}}</ref><ref name="kelsey-p14">{{Harvnb|Kelsey|1982|p=14}}</ref>
A commentary on the ''[[Genji Monogatari]]'' by [[Fujiwara no Teika]], known as ''Okuiri'' ("Inside Notes" or "Endnotes") has been designated as a National Treasure.<ref name="bowring-p85">{{Harvnb|Bowring|2004|p=85}}</ref><ref name="shiranea-p24">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008a|p=24}}</ref> Written around 1233 it is the second oldest Genji commentary, supplementing the oldest commentary, the Genji Shaku from 1160.<ref name="bowring-p85"/><ref name="caddeau-p51">{{Harvnb|Caddeau|2006|p=51}}</ref><ref name="shiranea-p24-138-150">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008a|pp=24, 138, 150}}</ref>

===History books and historical tales=== The oldest known<ref group="nb">Older texts such as the [[Tennōki]], [[Kokki]], [[Kyūji]] or [[Teiki]] from the 7th century have been lost, while others such as the [[Sangyō Gisho]] or the [[Taihō Code]] are relatively short or only exist as fragments.</ref> Japanese<ref group="nb">Composed in Japan on Japanese topics; most notably, the [[Japanese language]] is not meant here.</ref> large-scale works are historical books (''[[Kojiki]]'' and ''[[Nihon Shoki]]'') or regional cultural and geographical records (''[[fudoki]]'') compiled on imperial order in the early 8th century.<ref name="shirane-p1">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=1}}</ref><ref name="CHoJ-p470481">{{Harvnb|Brown|Hall|1993|pp=470, 481}}</ref><ref name="sakamoto-pxi">{{Harvnb|Sakamoto|1991|p=xi}}</ref> They were written with the aim of legitimizing the new centralized state under imperial rule by linking the origin of [[Japanese emperor|emperors]] to the [[Age of the Gods]].<ref name="shirane-p1"/><ref name="CHoJ-p352">{{Harvnb|Brown|Hall|1993|p=352}}</ref><ref name="sakamoto-pxiii">{{Harvnb|Sakamoto|1991|p=xiii}}</ref> The oldest of these historical books is the Kojiki ("Record of ancient matters") dating from 712 and composed by [[Ō no Yasumaro]] at the request of [[Empress Genmei]].<ref name="seeley-p41"/><ref name="frederic-p545">{{Harvnb|Frédéric|2005|p=545}}</ref><ref name="ono-p10"/> Written in ancient Japanese style using Chinese [[Ideogram|ideographs]], it presents the [[Japanese mythology|mythological origin of Japan]] and historical events up to the year 628.<ref name="frederic-p545"/><ref name="ono-p10"/> Shortly after the completion of the ''Kojiki'', the ''Nihon Shoki'' (or ''Nihongi'') appeared in 720, probably originating to an order by [[Emperor Tenmu]] in 681.<ref name="sakamoto-pxi"/><ref name="shirane-p44"/> It is a much more detailed version of the Kojiki, dating events and providing alternative versions of myths; it covers the time up to 697.<ref name="ono-p10"/><ref name="sakamoto-pxixiv">{{Harvnb|Sakamoto|1991|pp=xi, xiv}}</ref><ref name="seeley-p4647">{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|pp=46–47}}</ref> Compared to the Kojiki, it follows the model of [[Twenty-Four Histories|Chinese dynastic histories]] more closely in style and language, using orthodox classical Chinese.<ref name="sakamoto-pxiv">{{Harvnb|Sakamoto|1991|p=xiv}}</ref><ref name="newhistshinto-p29">{{Harvnb|Breen|Teeuwen|2010|p=29}}</ref> Both of these works provide the historical and spiritual basis for [[shinto]].<ref name="ono-p10">{{Harvnb|Ono|Woodard|2004|p=10}}</ref><ref name="CHoJ-p322">{{Harvnb|Brown|Hall|1993|p=322}}</ref>
In 713, [[Empress Genmei]] ordered provincial governors to compile official reports on the history, geography and local folk customs.<ref name="CHoJ-p469">{{Harvnb|Brown|Hall|1993|p=469}}</ref><ref name="frellesvig-p25">{{Harvnb|Frellesvig|2010|p=25}}</ref><ref name="lewin-p85">{{Harvnb|Lewin|1994|p=85}}</ref> These provincial [[gazetteer]]s are known as fudoki (lit. "Records of wind and earth") and provide valuable information about economic and ethnographic data, local culture and tales.<ref name="lewin-p85"/><ref name="shirane-p53">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=53}}</ref> Of more than 60 provincial records compiled in the early 8th century only five survived: one, the [[Izumo Province|Izumo]] Fudoki (733), in complete form and four, [[Bungo Province|Bungo]] (730s), [[Harima Province|Harima]] (circa 715), [[Hitachi Province|Hitachi]] (714–718) and [[Hizen Province|Hizen]] (730s) as fragments.<ref name="CHoJ-p469"/><ref name="frellesvig-p25"/><ref name="shirane-p53"/> The Nihon Shoki is the first official history of Japan and the first of a set of six national histories ([[Rikkokushi]]) compiled over a 200-year period on Chinese models.<ref name="shirane-p44">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=44}}</ref><ref name="shirane-p45">{{Harvnb|Shirane|2008b|p=45}}</ref><ref name="varley-p6768">{{Harvnb|Varley|2000|pp=67–68}}</ref> Based on these six histories, [[Sugawara no Michizane]] arranged historical events chronologically and thematically in the [[Ruijū Kokushi]] which was completed in 892.<ref name="burns-p246">{{Harvnb|Burns|2003|p=246}}</ref><ref name="piggot-p300">{{Harvnb|Piggott|1997|p=300}}</ref>
With the cessation of official missions to China and a general trend of turning away from Chinese-derived institutions and behavioral patterns in the latter part of the 9th century, the compilation of such national histories patterned on formal Chinese dynastic histories was abandoned.<ref name="varley-p68">{{Harvnb|Varley|2000|p=68}}</ref> With the development of [[kana]] script, new styles of uniquely Japanese literature such as the [[monogatari]] appeared around that time.<ref name="varley-p68"/> The newer style of historic writing that emerged during the [[Fujiwara clan|Fujiwara]] regency, at the turning point of ancient imperial rule and the classical era, was called historic tale (''rekishi monogatari'') and became influenced by the fictional tale, especially by the ''Tale of Genji'', with which it shared the scene-by-scene construction as fundamental difference to earlier historic writings.<ref group="nb">Other differences are: a realistic dialogue, the presentation of more than one viewpoint and the embellishment with a wealth of realistic detail.</ref><ref name="varley-p68"/><ref name="brownlee-p42">{{Harvnb|Brownlee|1991|p=42}}</ref><ref name="perkins-p13">{{Harvnb|Perkins|1998|p=13}}</ref> The oldest historical tale is the ''[[Eiga Monogatari]]'' ("A Tale of Flowering Fortunes"), giving a eulogistic chronological account of the Fujiwara from 946 to 1027, focusing particularly on [[Fujiwara no Michinaga]].<ref name="mccullough-p11200">{{Harvnb|McCullough|1991|pp=11, 200}}</ref><ref name="perkins-p1323">{{Harvnb|Perkins|1998|pp=13, 23}}</ref><ref name="brownlee-p46">{{Harvnb|Brownlee|1991|p=46}}</ref> It was largely<ref group="nb">30 out of 40 volumes.</ref> written by [[Akazome Emon]], probably shortly after the death of Michinaga in 1027.<ref name="perkins-p13"/><ref name="mccullough-p11">{{Harvnb|McCullough|1991|p=11}}</ref>
There are eleven National Treasures in the category of historical books including one manuscript of the Kojiki, five manuscripts of the Nihon Shoki, the Harima and Hizen Fudoki, two manuscripts of the Ruijū Kokushi and one of the Eiga Monogatari. All of these treasures are later copies and with the exception of the Eiga Monogatari, the complete content of the works has to be assembled from several of these (and other) fragmentary manuscripts or be inferred from other sources. The Kojiki, long neglected by scholars until the 18th century, was not preserved as well as the Nihon Shoki which has been studied from soon after its compilation. While being the oldest text in this list, the extant manuscript dating to the 14th century is the earliest entry.<ref name="bunkacho"/><ref name="frederic-p545"/>

===Others=== There are 18 Japanese book National Treasures that do not belong to any of the above categories. They cover 14 works of various types, including biographies, law or rulebooks, temple records, [[Sheet music|music scores]], a medical book and dictionaries.<ref name="bunkacho"/> Two of the oldest works designated are biographies of the [[Asuka period]] regent [[Prince Shōtoku|Shōtoku Taishi]]. The ''Shitennō-ji Engi'', alleged to have been an autobiography by Prince Shōtoku, described [[Shitennō-ji]], and may have been created to promote the temple.<ref name="lee-p40-42"/> The Shitennō-ji Engi National Treasure consists of two manuscripts: the alleged original discovered in 1007 at Shitennō-ji and a later transcription by [[Emperor Go-Daigo]].<ref name="lee-p40-42"/> Written by imperial order in the early 8th century, the ''[[Jōgū Shōtoku Hōō Teisetsu]]'' is the oldest extant biography of Shōtoku.<ref name="lee-p72">{{Harvnb|Lee|2007|p=72}}</ref><ref name="lee-p141">{{Harvnb|Lee|2007|p=141}}</ref><ref name="CHoJ-p482">{{Harvnb|Brown|Hall|1993|p=482}}</ref> It consists of a collection of anecdotes, legendary and miraculous in nature, which emphasize Shōtoku's Buddhist activities for the sake of imperial legitimacy, and stands at the beginning of Buddhist setsuwa literature.<ref name="lee-p72"/><ref name="CHoJ-p482"/> The oldest extant manuscript of the 803 ''Enryaku Kōtaishiki'', a compendium of rules concerned with the change of provincial governors from 782 to 803, has been designated as a National Treasure.<ref name="enryaku-kotaishi"/>
The oldest extant Japanese lexica date to the early Heian period.<ref name="lewin-p248">{{Harvnb|Lewin|1994|p=248}}</ref> Based on the Chinese [[Yupian]], the ''[[Tenrei Banshō Meigi]]'' was compiled around 830 by [[Kūkai]] and is the oldest extant [[Chinese character|character]] [[Japanese dictionary|dictionary made in Japan]].<ref name="Hausmann1991-p2618">{{cite book|last=Hausmann|first=Franz Josef|title=Wörterbücher: ein internationales Handbuch zur Lexikographie|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Kwqc7xso22wC&pg=PA2618|accessdate=2011-05-15|year=1991|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-012421-7|page=2618}}</ref><ref name="kozanji-nt"/> The ''Hifuryaku'' is a massive Chinese dictionary in 1000 fascicles listing the usage of words and characters in more than 1500 texts of diverse genres.<ref name="AdolphsonKamens2007-p182"/> Compiled in 831 by Shigeno Sadanushi and others, it is the oldest extant [[Japanese encyclopedias|Japanese proto-encyclopedia]].<ref name="lewin-p248"/><ref name="AdolphsonKamens2007-p182">{{Harvnb|Adolphson|Kamens|Matsumoto (eds.)|2007|p=182}}</ref> There are two National Treasures of the [[Ishinpō]], the oldest extant medical treatise of Japanese authorship compiled in 984 by Tanba Yasuyori.<ref name="Leslie1976-p327">{{cite book|last=Leslie|first=Charles M.|title=Asian medical systems: a comparative study|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jjDo1Xxj4XUC&pg=PA327|accessdate=2011-05-15|year=1976|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-03511-9|page=327}}</ref><ref name="ninnaji-cultass5"/><ref name="ishinpo-tnm"/> It is based on a large number of Chinese medical and pharmaceutical texts and contains knowledge about drug prescription, herbal lore, hygiene, acupuncture, [[moxibustion]], alchemy and magic.<ref name="Leslie1976-p327"/> The two associated treasures consist of the oldest extant (partial) and the oldest extant complete manuscript respectively.<ref name="ninnaji-cultass5"/><ref name="ishinpo-tnm"/>
Compiled between 905 and 927 by Tadahira, the [[Engishiki]] is the most respected legal compendium of the [[ritsuryō]] age and an important resource for the study of the Heian period court system.<ref name="totman-p119">{{Harvnb|Totman|2000|p=119}}</ref><ref name="Lu1997-p17"/><ref name="AdolphsonKamens2007-p43">{{Harvnb|Adolphson|Kamens|Matsumoto (eds.)|2007|p=43}}</ref> [[Emperor Daigo]] commanded its compilation; the Engishiki is according to David Lu an "invaluable" resource and "one of the greatest compilations of laws and precedents".<ref name="Lu1997-p17">{{cite book|last=Lu|first=David John|title=Japan: a documentary history|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xJxf1W74XSoC&pg=PA17|accessdate=2011-05-15|year=1997|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=978-1-56324-906-8|page=17}}</ref><ref name="AdolphsonKamens2007-p43"/> The three designated National Treasures of the Engishiki represent the oldest extant manuscript (Kujō edition) and the oldest extant edition of certain date (Kongōji edition).<ref name="seeley-p55"/> Two National Treasure manuscripts are related to music: the oldest extant [[kagura]] song book (''Kagura wagon hifu'') from around the 10th century and the oldest extant [[Saibara]] score (''Saibara fu'') which is traditionally attributed to [[Prince Munetaka]] but based on the calligraphy it appears to date to the mid-11th century.<ref name="saibarafu"/><ref name="saibarafu2"/> The ''Hokuzanshō'' consists of writings by [[Fujiwara no Kintō]] on court customs and the function of the [[Daijō-kan]]. The designated Kyoto National Museum manuscript of the Hokuzanshō from about 1000 is noted for one of the few early extant examples of [[hiragana]] use and for the oldest extant letters in [[kana]] written on the reverse side of the scroll.<ref name="seeley-p74">{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=74}}</ref><ref name="hokuzansho-tnm"/> Around the early 12th century a [[Shingon]] Buddhist priest compiled a dictionary with a large number of [[Variant Chinese character|variant form characters]] known as ''[[Ruiju Myōgishō]]''. The designated Kanchiin edition is the oldest extant complete manuscript of this work.<ref name="KindaichiHirano1989">{{cite book|last1=Kindaichi|first1=Haruhiko|last2=Hirano|first2=Umeyo|title=The Japanese language|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IZhFf3hlgNoC&pg=PA122|accessdate=2011-05-12|date=1989-12-15|publisher=Tuttle Publishing|isbn=978-0-8048-1579-6|page=122}}</ref><ref name="seeley-p126">{{Harvnb|Seeley|1991|p=126}}</ref> Among the youngest items in this list are two temple records: the ''Omuro Sōjōki'' giving an account of priests of imperial lineage at [[Ninna-ji]] starting from the [[Kanpyō (era)|Kanpyō era]], while the 1352 ''Tōhōki'' records treasures held at [[Tō-ji]].<ref name="omuro-sojoki1"/><ref name="omuro-sojoki2"/><ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Harvard Univ Asia Center | isbn = 0-674-80650-6 | last = Christine Guth Kanda | title = Shinzō: Hachiman imagery and its development | accessdate = 2011-05-14 | year = 1985 | page = 54 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=xKuEXrKXdOgC }}</ref> Kōbō Daishi's biography in an original manuscript penned by [[Emperor Go-Uda]] in 1315 has been designated as a National Treasure.<ref name="kobodaishiden"/>

{{Multiple issues| {{orphan|date=August 2010}} {{notability|Organizations|date=January 2010}} {{COI|date=January 2010}} {{autobiography|date=January 2010}} }} The '''Lollybot Collective''' is a multimedia [[art collective]] founded in [[Detroit, MI]].The Arts - Do-It-Yourself: The Lollybot Collective<{{cite web |url=http://thedetroiter.com/b2evoArt/blogs/index.php?blog=2&c=1&more=1&pb=1&tb=1&title=do_it_yourself_the_lollybot_collective |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828131134/http://thedetroiter.com/b2evoArt/blogs/index.php?blog=2&title=do_it_yourself_the_lollybot_collective&more=1&c=1&tb=1&pb=1 |archivedate=2008-08-28 |df= }}> The collective is made up of over fifty artists dedicated to positive change in a fun environment. Their gallery shows are well known for their laid back atmosphere, live shows and cheap beer. The collective is non-profit, all money is used to support the continuation of the artists' galleries and music. They do not take an independent commission from sold art pieces. Interaction between the audience and the art is highly encouraged. In their first show about accidents, an artist Curt Greene created a balanced sculpture that would fall apart if touched. In their second show "Feedback" the walls of the gallery were lined with brown paper allowing the audience to write responses to the art on the wall. This notion was used again in their third show "Restrictions". Video has also been used as a way to interact with art, at "Restrictions" there was a camera placed outside the bathroom that fed into a TV placed in the bathroom so that the person inside could see the line outside the bathroom.Alarm Press Magazine Spotlight <{{cite web |url=http://www.alarmpress.com/7535/music-interview/diy-venue-spotlight-the-lollybot-collective/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215184232/http://www.alarmpress.com/7535/music-interview/diy-venue-spotlight-the-lollybot-collective/ |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}> The collective was founded in 2007 by college friends Matthew Pritchard and Jeff Nolan who were attending The [[College for Creative Studies]] in Detroit. ==Key Members== There is no set membership in the collective, artists participate in the collective's shows on a revolving door basis. Yet there are many key members who have participated with the collective since its conception and are main supporters. Adam Ziskie
Ebenezer Archer Kling
Jeff Nolan (co-founder)
Kristina Rafalski
Lauren Moyer
Leyland DeVito
Matthew Pritchard (co-founder)
Maureen O'Brien ==Shows== There have been three shows curated and produced by The Lollybot Collective at various [[Detroit Art Galleries]] * ACCIDENTAL SHOW - October 27, 2007 at [[Scrummage University]], [[Detroit, MI]] Art show where the artists explored the idea of accidents in their pieces.Photos from the Accidental Show * FEEDBACK - February 16, 2008 at [[Cave Gallery]] located in the [[Russell Industrial Complex]] Artists made pieces that were hung on brown paper covered walls with a pencils so that the audience could respond and comment on the pieces. * RESTRICTIONS - February 28 through March 13, 2009 at [[Izzy's Raw Art Gallery]] Artists were given a restriction in which to create their piece by a computer generated, random list. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090421102444/http://lollybotcollective.com/ Lollybot Collective website] * [http://www.lollybot.blogspot.com/ Lollybot Collective blog] [[Category:American artist groups and collectives]] [[Category:Arts organizations based in Michigan]] [[Category:Culture of Detroit]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2007]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Michigan]]

The '''Miami Design District''', historically a part of [[Buena Vista (Miami)|Buena Vista]], is a neighborhood within the city of [[Miami]], [[Florida]], [[United States]], south of [[Lemon City, Florida|Lemon City]] (Little Haiti). It is roughly bound by [[U.S. Route 27 in Florida|North 36 St (US 27)]] to the south, North 43rd Street to the north, West First Avenue to the west and [[Biscayne Boulevard]] to the east.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miamidesigndistrict.net/pdf/MDDLocatorMap.pdf|title=District Design Map|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The Design District was made up primarily of old [[low-rise]] [[warehouse]]s that have been converted into retail spaces, art galleries, restaurants and cafés, but now includes a large amount of new construction, primarily for high-end retail.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/biz-monday/article1955427.html|title=Miami Design District’s transformation into a luxury shopping destination is underway|last=Cordle|first=Ina Paiva|date=2013-09-23|website=Miami Herald|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-09-28}}</ref> The Design District is in the crossroads of many prominent Miami neighborhoods, with the artsy [[Wynwood]] neighborhood to the south, Lemon City ([[Little Haiti]]) and the historic 1920s [[Buena Vista (Miami)|Buena Vista]] neighborhood to the north, and the wealthy [[Upper East Side (Miami)|Upper East Side]] neighborhoods to the east. After decades of falling to [[urban decay]], the Design District has risen to fame as a destination for the arts, [[design]], and [[fashion]].
It is home to over 130 art galleries, showrooms, creative services, [[architecture firm]]s, luxury fashion stores, antiques dealers, eateries and bars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miamidesigndistrict.net/browse.php|title=Directory of Fashion, Furniture & Watch Stores {{!}} Miami Design District|website=www.miamidesigndistrict.net|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
High-end brands like [[Louis Vuitton]], [[Christian Dior SE|Dior]], [[Prada]], [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Saint Laurent]] and [[Hermès|Hermes]] are located in the Design District as well as restaurants from award-winning chefs like Michael Schwartz and celebrities like [[Gloria Estefan|Gloria]] and [[Emilio Estefan]]; a public art collection with works from Buckminster Fuller, Marc Newsom and Urs Fischer as well as museums and galleries like the Institute for Contemporary Art, Miami, The [[De la Cruz Collection|de la Cruz Collection of Contemporary Art]] and Locust Projects.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cntraveler.com/gallery/what-to-do-in-the-miami-design-district|title=What to Do in the Miami Design District: Our Guide|last=Wood|first=Sara Liss,Jennifer M.|work=Condé Nast Traveler|access-date=2018-10-26|language=en}}</ref>
==History== The area of land that is now the Design District was once a pineapple farm in a neighborhood referred to as Buena Vista. Farm owner, T.V. Moore, built the historic Moore Building in the 1920’s for his family furniture business. The Moore Furniture Building was one of the first stores in the U.S. dedicated strictly to furniture.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.historicpreservationmiami.com/pdfs/2011%20designation%20reports%20updates/Buena_Vista_Post_Office_Designation_Report.pdf |title=Buena Vista Post Office Designation Report|last=|first=|date=|website=Historic Preservation Miami|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=29 October 2018}}</ref>
Today the area today known as the Design District. Signs and names with the name Buena Vista can still be seen throughout the area such as the Buena Vista Post Office, and Buena Vista School.<ref name=":1" />
By the 1980s and early-1990s, the Design District had fallen to [[urban decay]], and it wasn't until the late 1990s, and early 2000s, that art and design stores began opening up in the Design District. Throughout the 2000s, the Design District continued to grow in popularity, and with heavy public and private investment in the neighborhood, the streets and sidewalks were redone, and new trees were planted.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.departures.com/fashion/shopping/bal-harbour-shops-vs-design-district|title=Bal Harbour Shops vs. the Design District|last=Gross|first=Michael|date=2014-09-24|website=Departures|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
Credited to starting the district is [[Craig Robins]], who purchased many run-down buildings in the 18 square block area and persuaded many top designers, such as Alison Spear, [[Holly Hunt]] and Peter Page to relocate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://oceandrive.com/style/articles/craig-robins-jump-starts-the-design-district|title=Craig Robins Jump-Starts the Design District|last=McGee|first=Suzanne|date=2012-12-03|work=Ocean Drive|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
On 1 August 2016, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] issued a travel warning, advising pregnant women not to visit the Design District, [[Wynwood]], and [[Midtown Miami]] areas to avoid getting the [[Zika virus]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Daniel Chang|author2=Emily Cochrane|title=With 10 new Zika cases in Miami, CDC advises pregnant women to avoid Wynwood|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/health-care/article93057392.html|website=miamiherald.com|publisher=[[Miami Herald]]|accessdate=2 August 2016|date=1 August 2016|quote=The advisory extends to all expectant mothers, and women planning on becoming pregnant who have traveled to a one-square-mile area north of downtown Miami — including Wynwood, Midtown and the Design District — on or after June 15, said CDC Director Tom Frieden.}}</ref><ref name='cdc_zika'>{{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/zika/intheus/florida-update.html |title=Advice for people living in or traveling to Wynwood, a neighborhood in Miami, FL |publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention |access-date=1 August 2016}}</ref> Governor Rick Scott lifted the area’s “Zika Zone” designation on September 19, 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://therealdeal.com/miami/2017/06/28/wynwood-businesses-lost-as-much-as-40-in-revenue-due-to-zika-report/|title=Wynwood businesses lost as much as 40% of their revenue due to Zika: report|date=2017-06-28|work=The Real Deal Miami|access-date=2018-11-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Shopping== The District is home to many flagship luxury stores including [[Hermès]], [[Tom Ford]], [[Louis Vuitton]], [[Christian Louboutin]], [[Prada]], [[Celine]] and more.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/07/fashion/in-miami-luxury-know-no-limits.html|title=In Miami, Luxury Knows No Limits|last=Madigan|first=Nick|date=2014-12-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Currently, there are over 70 stores open in the District, with another 60 set to open by mid-2017.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/article19334178.html|title=Redesign of the Design District: New boutiques and restaurants arriving|last=Nehamas|first=Nicholas|date=2015-04-23|work=miamiherald|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
In 2009, the first luxury retailer opened in the Design District, [[Christian Louboutin]], marking a new era for the Design District. Later that year, [[Yohji Yamamoto]] opened in the Design District. In 2011, [[Louis Vuitton]] announced plans to open a Louis Vuitton store in the neighborhood by 2014 after announcing its closure of its [[Bal Harbour Shops]] store (the first Louis Vuitton store to open outside of [[New York City]]), along with opening other brands from the [[LVMH]] company in the Design District, including stores such as [[Sephora]], [[Marc Jacobs]], [[Givenchy]], and [[Fendi]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Louis Vuitton moving to Aventura Mall, Design District |url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2011-03-28/business/mh-louis-vuitton-20110328_1_aventura-mall-miami-design-district-miami-s-design-district |author=Walker, Elaine |newspaper=The Miami Herald |date=March 28, 2011 |accessdate=October 24, 2011}}</ref>
In October 2011, [[Hermes]], [[Cartier S.A.|Cartier]] and [[Dior]] announced plans to move their stores from [[Bal Harbour Shops]] to the Design District in late 2011 and 2012.<ref name="hermes">{{cite news |title = Hermes moving to Miami Design District|url = http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/10/06/2442328/hermes-moving-to-miami-design.html|author = Walker, Elaine|newspaper = The Miami Herald|date = October 7, 2011|accessdate = October 24, 2011}}</ref> Design Within Reach opened an 11,000-square foot design store in the district on Feb 1st, 2013. <ref name="Miami Curbed">{{cite web|url=http://miami.curbed.com/archives/2012/12/17/design-within-reach-in-the-design-district.php|title=Design District Drama|last=McCaughan|first=Sean|date=2012-12-17|website=Miami.Curbed.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref>
The three-story, 13,000-square-foot [[Hermès]] store opened in November 2015 and is only the third U.S. flagship after [[Madison Avenue]] in [[New York City]] and [[Rodeo Drive]] in [[Beverly Hills]], CA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/article43208754.html|title=Hermès opens flagship store in Design District; other new tenants announced|last=Nehamas|first=Nicholas|date=2015-11-05|website=miamiherald|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-11-24}}</ref>
By the end of 2017, Dacra will have 120 stores open on its own property, and other property owners will have another 40. Stores to open include, Be Miami, Aesop, Citco, Creed, [[Dior]], [[Dolce & Gabbana]], Faubourg Galerie & Café, Isabel Marant, Joseph, [[Loro Piana]], Rag & Bone, [[Tod’s]], [[Tory Burch]], [[Van Cleef & Arpels]], Saint Laurent, Sevan Biçakçi and Zilli.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://therealdeal.com/miami/blog/2015/11/11/more-luxury-brands-heading-for-miamis-design-district/|title=More luxury brands heading to Miami's Design District|last=Corlde|first=Ina|date=2015-11-11|website=The Real Deal Miami|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-11-24}}</ref>
==Restaurants== The Design District offers a variety of dining options, including [[James Beard]] Award-winning chef/owner Michael Schwartz's Michael's Genuine and the Cypress Tavern.<ref name=":0" /> Future 2016 offerings will include ABC Kitchen from chef [[Jean-Georges Vongerichten]], and four restaurants from decorated [[Michelin Guide]]star chef [[Joël Robuchon]]. All four restaurants, L'Atelier, Le Bar, La Boutique and La Terrace will open in what will be called Paradise Plaza, on the north end of the Design District, part of the area's Phase Three build out.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.miami.com/jo-l-robuchon-open-three-restaurants-miami039s-design-district-article|title=Joël Robuchon to open three restaurants in Miami's Design District|last=Benn|first=Evan S.|date=2015-04-23|work=Miami.com|access-date=2018-04-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Art Galleries and Art Events== [[Image:Fendi showroom in the Miami Design District 20081206.jpg|thumb|right|A portion of the interior of the [[Fendi]] art gallery/showroom in the Miami Design District, December, 2008]] [[File:Miami Design District north entrance 20110216.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Northern entrance to Design District]]
The Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami (ICA Miami), promotes the work of contemporary artists, and the exchange of art and ideas throughout the Miami region and internationally. Through exhibitions, programs, and collections, ICA showcases the work of established and emerging artists, and aims to advance the public appreciation and understanding of innovative and experimental art.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.icamiami.org/about/|title=About the Institute of Contemporary Art, Miami|work=Institute of Contemporary Art Miami|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Demographics== {{As of|2000}}, the population of the Miami Design District had 1,116 people. The zip codes for the Miami Design District include 33127 and 33137. The area covers {{convert|0.249|sqmi|km2}}. {{As of|2000}}, there were 522 males and 594 females. The median age for males were 26.2 years old, while the median age for females were 25.4 years old. The average household size had 3.1 people, while the average family size had 3.6 members. The percentage of married-couple families (among all households) was 32.9%, while the percentage of married-couple families with children (among all households) was 17.5%, and the percentage of single-mother households (among all households) was 20.7%. 5.8% of population in other group homes. The percentage of never-married males 15 years old and over was 19.2%, while the percentage of never-married females 15 years old and over was 19.5%.<ref name=DesDis>{{cite web |url=http://www.city-data.com/neighborhood/Design-District-Miami-FL.html |title=Demographics of Miami Design District, FL. |publisher=[[city-data]]|accessdate=2009-08-31}}</ref>
{{As of|2000}}, the percentage of people that speak English not well or not at all made up 20.2% of the population. The percentage of residents born in Florida was 41.6%, the percentage of people born in another U.S. state was 12.1%, and the percentage of native residents but born outside the U.S. was 7.3%, while the percentage of foreign born residents was 39.0%.<ref name="DesDis"/>
==Transportation== The Design District is served by [[Miami Metrobus|Metrobus]] throughout the area, the City of Miami Trolley Biscayne-Brickell route and by the [[Metrorail (Miami)|Miami Metrorail]] in adjoining [[Allapattah]] less than a mile due west at:
*{{color box|#{{MDM color|Green}}}}{{color box|#{{MDM color|Orange}}}} [[Allapattah (Metrorail station)|Allapattah]] ([[U.S. Route 27 in Florida|36th Street/US 27]] and NW 12th Avenue)
==Education== [[Miami-Dade County Public Schools]] operates area public schools:
*[[Design and Architecture High School]]
==See also== *[[Arts & Entertainment District]] *[[Medimix International]] *[[Midtown Miami]] *[[Wynwood]] *[[Buena Vista (Miami)|Buena Vista]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Miami Design District}} {{wikivoyage|Miami/Design District|Design District}} * [http://www.miamidesigndistrict.net/ Miami Design District] * [http://www.designmiami.com/ Design Miami / Art Basel] * [http://www.designdistrictmag.com Miami Design District Magazine: Art + Design + Entertainment + Events]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Painting | alt=See adjacent text. | image=Le train de nuit.jpg | image_size=300px | title=Night Train | other_language_1=French | other_title_1=Le train de nuit | artist=[[Paul Delvaux]] | year=1947 | height_metric=153 | width_metric=210 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=Toyama | museum=The Museum of Modern Art }} '''''Night Train''''' (''Le train de nuit'') is a 1947 painting by Belgian artist [[Paul Delvaux]], famous for his paintings of female nudes. The painting is 153 x 210 centimetres and is currently housed in the [[Museum of Modern Art, Toyama]].http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/drawings-watercolors/paul-delvaux-le-train-de-nuit-5289427-details.aspx#top[http://www.pref.toyama.jp/branches/3042/e_page/e_information.htm The Museum of Modern Art] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130102155852/http://www.pref.toyama.jp/branches/3042/e_page/e_information.htm |date=2013-01-02 }} Trapped in a loveless marriage, Delvaux wished "to paint boredom, sadness and the desire to get away from it all... There is this nostalgic aspect about waiting rooms where people pass by briefly before leaving... I tried to capture the beauty of the waiting room in an empty station. People are not necessary, for a station has its own life".Quoted in ''La Lanterne'', 29 January, 1970. According to the [[Christie's]], this work is "a powerful poetic expression of the overwhelming sense of paralysis and imprisonment Delvaux was experiencing at the time":
Depicting the stillness and ennui of a station waiting room infused with the languid erotic mystery of a sleeping nude and a lone train pulling into a station, the picture's main subject seems to be the articulation of a terrifying emptiness. The moonlit station clock and the empty gaze of the upright receptionist sitting to attention at her desk, echoed by her reflection in the mirror, seem to emphasize the frozen nature of time and space extending into infinity, while the nude lies bored and restless underneath a bleak sign advertising the endless cycle of arrivals and departures.
== References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:1947 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Paul Delvaux]] [[Category:Paintings in Japan]] [[Category:Trains in art]] {{20C-painting-stub}}

revision.text:
In the fields of [[bibliography]] and [[bookselling]], '''prize books''' (also known as '''prize bindings'''), are a category of finely bound books once given as prizes and awards in educational institutions primarily in [[England]], [[Ireland]], and the [[Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Morris |first1=John |date= September 1989|title=Reviewed Work: Gold-Tooled Bookbindings Commissioned by Trinity College, Dublin in the Eighteenth Century. (Studies in the History of Irish Bookbinding: 1) by Joseph McDonnell and Patrick Healy |url= |journal= The Burlington Magazine |volume=131 |issue=1038 |pages=656–657 }}</ref> This tradition flourished in Latin schools in continental [[Europe]] from the mid-17th century until the introduction of publishers bindings after about 1830. Books continued to be given as prizes at academic ceremonies, but the only distinguishing feature are typically special inscriptions and/or [[bookplates]].
==History in UK== In the [[United Kingdom]], the tradition of special prize bindings persisted until the mid-20th century with the demise of traditional hand binding. Most titles consist of classical works in the [[humanities]] published in unbound print runs for this purpose. Schools would contract with a local [[bindery]] to prepare prize editions stamped or [[Paper embossing|embossed]] with the logo of the school. The editions are often made to resemble the fine bindings of the 18th century and are prized by booksellers for their classical appearance. They are often mistaken as ex-school library books but can be distinguished by a prize inscription, lack of [[call number]], and general higher quality of the binding.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.burtongrammar.co.uk/category/life-and-times/speech-day/prize-books Prize books at the Burton Grammar School] * [http://www.geheugenvannederland.nl/?/en/collecties/boekbanden/prijsbanden Prize Bindings of the Koniklijke Bibliotheek] * [http://www.hrc.utexas.edu/collections/books/holdings/prize/ English and Dutch Prize Bindings]
[[Category:Books]]

revision.text:
[[File:Gammel Dok - DAC.jpg|thumb|Danish Architecture Centre in Copenhagen, a project co-developed by Realdania]]
'''Realdania''' is a private association in [[Denmark]] which supports projects in architecture and planning. It was established in 2000 following the sale of [[Realkredit Danmark]] to [[Danske Bank]], when a fund of approximately 20 billion kroner (EUR 2.7 billion) was put aside for "philanthropic" purposes.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS208747+22-Aug-2011+BW20110822 "Greylock Capital Receives Investment from Realdania"] (press release), ''Reuters'', 22 August 2011. Accessed 2 February 2016.</ref> Realkredit Danmark was owned and controlled by its members (mortgage lenders), and this set-up was kept in Realdania.
==Structure== Realdania is often erroneously called a [[Foundation (non-profit)|private charitable foundation]], but Realdania's legal structure is that of an association operating as a business and not a foundation.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} Only owners of real estate in Denmark can become members of Realdania and participate in electing members of the board. Realdania has several subsidiaries. Realdania's closed structure has provoked criticism, and the association's funds has been called "stray billions" since they are controlled by a small network of people.<ref>[http://www.business.dk/finans/herreloese-milliarder-skal-toejles Jens Chr. Hansen: "Herreløse milliarder skal tøjles"], ''Berlingske.dk'', 25 March 2009 (in Danish).</ref><ref>[http://politiken.dk/kultur/arkitektur/ECE1018820/hvem-holder-oeje-med-realdanias-milliarder/ Jens Lenler & Torben Benner: "Hvem holder øje med Realdanias milliarder?"], ''Politiken.dk'', 17 July 2010 (in Danish).</ref>
==Stated purposes== Its activity is concentrated on supporting projects in [[architecture]] and the built environment and is focused on three areas: cities, buildings and architectural heritage. The statutes of Realdania state that the association's purpose is to: # Support non-profit and charitable purposes, primarily in the field of the built environment, and primarily in Denmark, # Run an investment company, # Acquire shares in companies that are engaged in activities pertaining to the built environment, # Provide services related to the built environment, and # Acquire and construct real property in order to preserve the built heritage and develop Danish building practice.<ref>[http://www.realdania.dk/Om-Realdania/~/media/20E9BC8DAD3A49D8B5F07AC37994D41F.ashx Realdania's Statues (in Danish, PDF)]</ref>
It can be seen that investment activities predominate other ones, so that the avowed "philanthropic" or "charitable" nature of Realdania does not particularly stand out. At the end of 2011 Realdania's endowment stood at EUR 2.1 billion. <ref>{{cite web|accessdate=31 August 2012|url=http://www.realdania.dk/english.aspx|title=Overview|publisher=Realdania|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904041536/http://www.realdania.dk/English.aspx|archivedate=4 September 2012|df=}}</ref>
==Projects== Projects supported by Realdania include ARoS Aarhus Kunstmuseum in [[Aarhus]]<ref>[http://www.aros.dk/?setlanguage=2 ARoS]</ref> and the Brewery Site in Copenhagen, commissioned from Dutch architect [[Rem Koolhaas]].<ref>[http://www.dac.dk/en/dac-life/copenhagen-x-gallery/ongoing-or-future-projects/the-brewery-site-project/?cphxredirect=true Brewery Site]</ref> This last real estate development, the so-called "Blox" building including the [[Danish Architecture Centre]], was inaugurated in 2018. Designed on the assumption that "the city has become too calm and beautified," it has been criticized as a "gloomy glass monolith."<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/may/01/blox-danish-architecture-centre-copenhagen</ref>
==See also== *[[Architecture of Denmark]] *[[List of wealthiest charitable foundations]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Jørgen Nue Møller (2009). ''Penge til Huse - Fra kreditforening til filantropisk virksomhed''. Realdania. {{ISBN|8799161842}}. {{dk icon}}
==External links== *[http://www.realdania.dk/ Realdania website] *[http://www.realdania.dk/~/media/D04AB932D39A4291ABF62BB926A72808.ashx Realdania Development and Change]
{{coord|55.6795|12.5645|type:landmark_region:DK|display=title}}
[[Category:Copenhagen architecture]] [[Category:Foundations based in Denmark]] [[Category:Conservation and environmental foundations]] [[Category:Arts foundations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2000]]

{{For|the Maryland politician|Robert A. McKee}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} {{BLP sources|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Robert McKee | image = Mackee.jpg| | caption = Robert McKee at the Story Seminar given at the Tel Aviv Cinematheque, October 2005 | birth_date = 1941 | birth_place = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] | occupation = Author, Lecturer, Story Consultant | website = [https://mckeestory.com mckeestory.com] }}
'''Robert McKee''' (born 1941) is an [[author]], [[lecturer]] and [[story consultant]] who is widely known for his popular "Story [[Seminar]]", which he developed when he was a professor at the [[University of Southern California]]. McKee is the author of ''Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting'', ''Dialogue: the Art of Verbal Action for Stage, Page and Screen'' and ''Storynomics: Story-Driven Marketing in the Post-Advertising World''. McKee also has the blog and online writers' resource "[https://www.storylogue.com/ Storylogue]".
Robert McKee’s “Story Seminars” have been held around the globe including [[Boston]], [[Moscow]], [[Amsterdam]], [[Beijing]], [[Mumbai]], [[Paris]], [[Rio de Janeiro]] and yearly in [[New York City]], [[Los Angeles]], and [[London]]. The 3-day seminar teaches writers the principles of [[storytelling]]. McKee's one-day "[[Genre]] Seminars" teach writers the conventions of different styles of storytelling including [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]], [[Comedy film|comedy]], [[horror film|horror]], [[Romance film|love story]], [[Action (fiction)|action story]], and writing for [[Television program|television]].
Rather than teaching story as a "mechanical" form, McKee gained notoriety for teaching story principles, allowing writers for [[Theatre|theater]], [[Novel|novels]], [[film]] and [[television]] freedom to apply them as they wish provided the story ultimately “works”.
After consulting on business storytelling for various multinational companies including [[Microsoft]], [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Hewlett-Packard]], [[Time Warner]], and [[Siemens]], in the fall of 2013 McKee launched a seminar for the business community in [[Los Angeles]], [[New York City]], [[Beijing]], and [[Malta]]. In 2018, McKee partnered with digital marketer and Skyword CEO [[Tom Gerace]] to write ''Storynomics: Story-Driven Marketing in the Post-Advertising World.'' Storynomics, and the accompanying seminar, instructs leaders, managers and marketers how to use story in [[strategic management]], [[brand management]], and [[Business communication|business communications]].
== Early life in the theater == Robert McKee began his theater career at the age of 9, playing the title role in a community theater production of 'Martin the Shoemaker'. He continued acting as a teenager in theater productions in his hometown of [[Detroit, Michigan]]. Upon receiving the Evans scholarship, he attended the [[University of Michigan]] and earned a Bachelor's degree in [[English Literature]]. While an undergraduate, he acted in and directed over thirty productions. McKee's creative writing professor was the noted [[Kenneth Thorpe Rowe]].
After completing his Bachelor of Arts degree, McKee toured with the APA (Association of Producing Artists) Repertory Company, appearing on Broadway alongside [[Helen Hayes]], [[Rosemary Harris]] and [[Will Geer]]. He then received the Professional Theater Fellowship and returned to [[Ann Arbor|Ann Arbor, Michigan]] to earn his Master's degree in [[Theater|Theater Arts]].
Upon graduating, McKee directed the Toledo Repertory Company, acted with the American Drama Festival, and became Artistic Director of the Aaron Deroy Theater. From there he traveled to London to accept the position of [[Artist-in-residence]] at the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]] where he studied Shakespearean production at the [[Old Vic]] theatre. He then returned to New York City and spent the next seven years as an actor/director in [[Broadway theater|Broadway]].
== Mid-life in the film industry == After deciding to move his career to film, McKee attended Cinema School at the University of Michigan. While there, he directed two short films: ''A Day Off'', which he also wrote, and ''Talk To Me Like The Rain'', adapted from a one-act play by [[Tennessee Williams]]. These two films won the Cine Eagle Award, awards at the Brussels and Grenoble Film Festivals, and various prizes at the Delta, Rochester, Chicago and Baltimore Film Festivals.
In 1979, McKee moved to Los Angeles, where he began to write screenplays and work as a story analyst for [[United Artists]] and [[NBC]]. He sold his first screenplay ''Dead Files'' to AVCO/Embassy Films, after which he joined the WGA ([http://www.wga.org/ Writers Guild of America]). His next screenplay, ''Hard Knocks'', won the National Screenwriting Contest, and since then McKee has had eight feature film screenplays purchased or optioned, including the feature film script ''Trophy'' for [[Warner Bros.]] (Only one of these films, however, was produced). In addition to his screenplays, McKee has had a number of scripts produced for television series such as ''[[Quincy, M.E.]]'' (starring [[Jack Klugman]]), ''[[Columbo#Mrs. Columbo spin-off|Mrs. Columbo]]'' (starring [[Kate Mulgrew]]), ''[[Spenser: for Hire]]'' and ''[[Kojak]]'' (starring [[Telly Savalas]]).
== Starting the STORY seminar == In 1983, as [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright Scholar]], McKee joined the faculty of the [[USC School of Cinematic Arts|School of Cinema-Television]] at the [[University of Southern California|University of Southern California (USC)]], where he began offering his famous STORY Seminar class. A year later, McKee opened the course to the public, giving a 3-day, 30-hour intensive class to sold-out audiences around the world.
Since 1984, more than 50,000 students have taken McKee's course, at various cities around the world: Los Angeles, New York, London, Paris, Sydney, Toronto, Boston, Las Vegas, San Francisco, Helsinki, Oslo, Munich, Tel Aviv, Auckland, Singapore, Barcelona, Stockholm, São Paulo and more. In March 2011 and again in 2012, he taught a four-day seminar in Bogotá, Colombia. In February 2012 he taught another four-day seminar in the Ramoji film city of Hyderabad in India. He did the same in [[Amsterdam]], March 2014.
McKee's current lecture series includes the 3-day "Story Seminar", 1-day "Genre Seminars" (teaching the conventions of [[Romance film|love Story]], [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]], [[comedy]], [[Horror fiction|horror]], [[Action fiction|action]] and writing for [[television]]) and the 1-day “Storynomics Seminar”, teaching the application of storytelling principles in the business and marketing world (co-lectured with CEO of Skyword [[Tom Gerace]]).
McKee continues to be a project consultant to major film and television production companies, corporations and governments around the world, as well major software firms such as [[Microsoft]]. In addition, several companies such as [[ABC Studios|ABC]], [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]], [[Miramax]], [[PBS]], [[Nickelodeon]] and [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]] regularly send their creative and writing staffs to his lectures.
== Life and awards == Robert McKee is among the most widely known screenwriting [[lecturers]]. McKee's former students include over 65 [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] winners, 200 [[Emmy Award]] winners, 100 WGA ([[Writers Guild of America]]) Award winners and 50 DGA ([[Directors Guild of America]]) Award winners (all participated in McKee's course before or after winning their award; not all were awarded for writing), the British Book of the Year Award and the [[Pulitzer Prize for Feature Writing]]. Some recent notable former students to win or be nominated for Oscars include [[Akiva Goldsman]] for his screenplay "[[A Beautiful Mind (film)|A Beautiful Mind]]," [[Peter Jackson]] (writer/director of "[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|Lord of the Rings]] I, II and III”), [[Andrew Stanton]] (“[[WALL-E|Wall*E]],” “[[Finding Nemo]]”) and [[Paul Haggis]] (“[[Million Dollar Baby]],” “[[Quantum of Solace]]”).
He was profiled by Bob Simon of ''60 Minutes'' for [[CBS News]], and by [[CNN]] who also reviewed the Story Seminar. Notable writers and actors such as [[Geoffrey Rush]], [[Paul Haggis]], [[Akiva Goldsman]], [[William Goldman]], [[Joan Rivers]], [[David Bowie]], [[Kirk Douglas]], [[John Cleese]], Tony Kaye, [[Steven Pressfield]], among many others have taken his seminar.<ref name="MT" />
In 1990, Robert McKee was brought to [[New Zealand]] by the NZ Film Commission, and delivered a three-day seminar on screenplay and story structure in [[Auckland]] and [[Wellington]]. In the audience were [[Jane Campion]] and [[Peter Jackson]], the latter of which went on to write and direct ''[[Heavenly Creatures]]'', ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|The Lord of the Rings]]'', and ''[[King Kong (2005 film)|King Kong]]''.
In 2000, McKee won the [https://web.archive.org/web/20061207213752/http://www.editor.net/k-k/old/prize99.htm 1999 International Moving Image Book Award] for his book ''Story'' ([[ReganBooks|Regan Books]]/[[HarperCollins]]). The book, currently in its 19th printing in the United States and its 14th printing in the [[UK|United Kingdom]], has become required reading for film and cinema schools at [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Yale]], [[UCLA]], [[University of Southern California|USC]] and [[Tulane University|Tulane]] universities.[[Robert McKee#cite note-autogenerated1-2|<sup>[2]</sup>]][[Robert McKee#cite note-3|<sup>[3]</sup>]] The book was on the [[Los Angeles Times]] best-seller list for 20 weeks. It is translated into over 20 languages.
In 2017 McKee was inducted into the [https://www.finaldraft.com/company/hall-fame-awards/ Hall of Fame at the Final Draft Awards], an honor that recognizes professionals who have had a "profound influence on the industry"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.finaldraft.com/company/hall-fame-awards/|title=Hall of Fame Awards {{!}} Final Draft®|work=Final Draft®|access-date=2018-06-19|language=en-US}}</ref> joining peers such as [[Lawrence Kasdan]] and [[Steven Zaillian]].
McKee's other credits include writing and presenting the [[BBC]] series ''Filmworks'', the [[Channel Four]] series ''Reel Secrets'', the [[BAFTA]] Award-winning ''J'accuse Citizen Kane'' television program which he wrote and presented, and the writing of [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109036 ''Abraham''], the four-hour mini-series on [[Turner Network Television]] (TNT) that starred [[Richard Harris]], [[Barbara Hershey]] and [[Maximilian Schell]].
==Books==
* ''Story: Substance, Structure, Style and the Principles of Screenwriting'' (1997) * ''Dialogue: the Art of Verbal Action for Stage, Page and Screen'' (2016) * ''Storynomics: Story-Driven Marketing in the Post-Advertising World'' (2018)
==Criticism== McKee has been criticized by writer [[Joe Eszterhas]], for teaching screenwriting without ever having a script of his made into a film.<ref>[http://movies2.nytimes.com/2006/09/17/books/review/Queenan.t.html 'Basic Instinct'] — New York Times article by Joe Queenan, September 17, 2006</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/arts/filmprogramme/filmprogramme_20070209.shtml |title=— Film programme interview, 9 February 2007' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=December 27, 2013}}</ref> (However, McKee is credited as writer of the 1994 TV movie ''Abraham''.<ref>{{IMDb name|571210}}</ref>) McKee has responded to such criticisms, saying, "The world is full of people who teach things they themselves cannot do", while admitting that even though he sold all of his written screenplays, he still lacks their screen credit since they were only optioned and not ever produced by the studios.<ref name="MT">[http://www.umich.edu/~newsinfo/MT/95/Jun95/mt21j95.html Michigan Today – June 1995] — interview with Brett Forrest</ref>
While McKee's work might appear to be a fresh approach to story structure, many of the ideas he discusses have been around since [[Aristotle]] and notably appear in the work of [[William Archer (critic)|William Archer]],<ref name="Archer1912">{{cite book|author=William Archer|title=Play-making: A Manual of Craftsmanship|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5Xs_AAAAYAAJ|accessdate=March 31, 2013|year=1912|publisher=Small, Maynard}}</ref> [[John Howard Lawson]] and [[Alexander Mackendrick]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} Nevertheless, McKee himself tells his students that Aristotle is the basis for much of what he teaches and he often distributes some of John Howard Lawson's writings at his seminar: he acknowledges his forebears and never claims that he is inventing a brand new approach to story telling.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleid=305 | title = Robert McKee – Lessons of a screenwriting guru | author = Ian Parker | date = January 27, 2004 | accessdate = March 31, 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130206102146/http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleid=305 | archivedate = February 6, 2013 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Furthermore he claims that much of what he teaches was common knowledge 50 or 60 years ago, but that screenwriters have lost touch with the fundamentals of storytelling. In a CBC interview he said that to give his lecture in the 1930s, 40s or 50s "would have been ludicrous".<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lc5QRxZidNQ | title = Robert McKee on The Hour with George Stroumboulopoulos | accessdate = March 31, 2013 | date = July 11, 2008}}</ref> McKee also appears and is criticized in several works, for example, ''Missionnaire'' by French author [[Joann Sfar]].
==In popular culture== In the [[Charlie Kaufman]]-penned film ''[[Adaptation (film)|Adaptation.]]'', McKee's character was portrayed by the [[Emmy Award]]-winning actor [[Brian Cox (actor)|Brian Cox]]. In the Oscar-winning movie, the desperate screenwriter Charlie Kaufman (played by [[Nicolas Cage]]) reluctantly goes to McKee's course, but then – after being "shaken" by McKee's tough-style response to his claim that "nothing happens in the real world" – Kaufman asks McKee to meet in person to discuss his failure to write the [[film adaptation]] he is working on.
Though the story depicts McKee as little more than an amalgam of hack clichés on the subject of screen writing, Charlie's slacker brother Donald uses the knowledge obtained attending the famous seminar to write a [[spec script]] he then sells for a large amount of money through his brother's agent. The film then concludes with the very ending that McKee is ridiculed for recommending, as well as a voice-over epilogue in which — by means of voice-over narration — Cage's Kaufman character admonishes himself for disobeying a cardinal rule of McKee's to avoid voice-over narration.
McKee appeared on the ''[[The Simpsons|Simpsons]]'' episode "[[Caper Chase]]" as himself.<ref>http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/yale-harvard-war-bogs-down-overstuffed-simpsons-253107</ref>
== Anecdotes == * McKee claims in his seminars that he does ''not'' say not to use voice-over narration. There is some truth to the scene in ''Adaptation'' however, as he vehemently teaches that using voice-over to substitute for telling the story via action and dialogue is weak,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.storylogue.com/docs/question-answer.html?documentId=1345 | title = Q&A: What did you think of the voice-over in GOODFELLAS? | author = Robert McKee | date = August 10, 2013 | accessdate=September 5, 2013}}</ref> whereas he teaches that voice-over used to counterpoint and enrich the story can be wonderful.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://peachseedmonkey.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/mckeevoiceovertechnique.pdf | title = A Study in Voice Over Narration from two recent films, SAVAGES and BEASTS OF THE SOUTHERN WILD. | author = Robert McKee | date = August 13, 2012 | accessdate=September 5, 2013}}</ref> * McKee is known to object to the French-originated "[[auteur theory]]", which states that the director is the de facto author of a movie. McKee states otherwise, that the writer/screenwriter is in fact the most important creator of the movie. * In a ''[[Haaretz]]'' article,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasite/spages/782893.html | title = וודי אלן לא עשה עלייה (in Hebrew, rough translation "Woody Allen did increase") | date = November 2, 2006 | accessdate = March 31, 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110605041310/http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasite/spages/782893.html | archivedate = June 5, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> McKee was quoted as saying in front of a Tel Aviv audience that Israelis have a rough sense of humor, completely different from the known worldwide Jewish one, since Israelis are living in a harsh reality which leads them to lose their sense of humor.

{{Infobox Organization |name = Royal Canadian Academy of Arts |image = Canadian Academy of Arts 1880.gif |image_border = |size = |caption = Canadian Academy of Arts, 1880 |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = RCA |motto = |formation = 1880 |extinction = |type = Arts organization |status = Active |purpose = Advocate and public voice, educator and network |headquarters = [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]] |location = |region_served = Canada |membership = Over 790 |language = English, French |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = |remarks = }}
The '''Royal Canadian Academy of Arts''' ('''RCA''') is a Canadian [[art]]s-related organization that was founded in 1880.
==History== ===1880 to 1890=== The title of Royal Canadian Academy of Arts was received from [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]] on 16 July 1880. The [[Governor General of Canada]], the [[John Campbell, 9th Duke of Argyll|Marquess of Lorne]], was its first patron. The painter [[Lucius Richard O'Brien|Lucius O’Brien]] was its first President.
The objects of the Academy as stated in the 1881 publication of the organization's constitution<ref name=RCA_Act1881>{{cite book|title=Constitution and Laws of the Royal Canadian Academy of the Arts|year=1881|publisher=Globe Printing Co., Printer|location=Toronto|page=1|url=http://ebooks.library.ualberta.ca/local/cihm_12893}}</ref> were three-fold: *First - the institution of a National Gallery at the seat of Government; *Second - the holding of Exhibitions in the principal cities of the Dominion; *Third - the establishment of Schools of Art and Design.
In the same publication, two levels of membership were described: Academicians and Associates. No more than forty individuals could be Academicians at one time, while the number of Associates was not limited. All Academicians were required to give an example of their work to the collection of the [[National Gallery of Canada|National Gallery]]. They were also permitted to show more pieces in Academy-sponsored exhibitions than Associates.<ref name=RCA_Act1881 />
The inaugural exhibition was held in Ottawa and the first Academicians were inducted, including the first woman Academician, [[Charlotte Schreiber]]. Through the next 10 years, the Academy held annual exhibitions, often in cooperation with regional artists' societies. Exhibitions in Toronto were a joint project of the Academy and the [[Ontario Society of Artists]], while those held in Montreal were held in partnership with the [[Montreal Artists Association]]. Exhibitions were also held in St. John, [[New Brunswick]], and [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]].<ref name=RCA_Report1886>{{cite book|title=Report and review of financial position and prospective policy of the Academy to His Excellency the Most Hon. the Marquis of Lansdowne, Governor-General, Patron of the Royal Canadian Academy of Arts, 1886|year=1886|publisher=Royal Canadian Academy of Arts|location=Ottawa|url=http://ebooks.library.ualberta.ca/local/cihm_45606}}</ref> Additional academicians and associates were added each year until the membership had more than doubled by 1890. Members were drawn from all areas of the country and included anglophones and francophones. Men continued to out-number women and those female members were identified as painters not as designers or architects.<ref name=RCA_Founding />
As Academicians joined, they donated an example of their work to the National Gallery of Canada, building the collection of the as-yet unincorporated institution. A temporary home was found for the collection in a building next to the Supreme Court of Canada and the first curator, John W. H. Watts, RCA was appointed to begin organizing exhibitions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our History: Pre 1900|url=http://www.gallery.ca/en/about/pre-1900.php|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|accessdate=30 October 2013}}</ref>
The third objective—to encourage the teaching of art and design in Canada—was found to be more challenging to address with the limited financial resources available to them.<ref name=RCA_Report1886 />
===1891 to present=== Canadian landscape painter [[Homer Watson]] was elected as an associate, became a full member and later became president of the Academy.
The centennial year of the Academy was honoured by a 35 cent, 3 colour postage stamp.<ref>[https://archive.is/20130116010109/http://collectionscanada.gc.ca/ourl/res.php?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&url_tim=2012-07-24T13:57:38Z&url_ctx_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=2218678&rfr_id=info:sid/collectionscanada.gc.ca:pam&lang=eng Credit: Library and Archives Canada; Copyright: Canada Post Corporation]</ref> The stamp features an image of the original centre block of the [[Parliament Buildings (Canada)|Parliament Buildings]] and the text "Royal Canadian Academy of Arts, 1880–1980", with the name "[[Thomas Fuller (architect)|Thomas Fuller]]", a member of the Academy and the Dominion Architect of Canada <ref>[http://www.historicplaces.ca/en/pages/4_thomas-fuller.aspx Dominion Architect]</ref> who had designed the original building.
==Members== The Academy is composed of members from across Canada representing over twenty visual arts disciplines. This list is not inclusive. See also [[:Category:Members of the Royal Canadian Academy of Arts]].

page.title: The Coronation of Inês de Castro in 1361

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Le_Couronnement_d%27Inès_de_Castro_en_1361_-_Pierre-Charles_Comte_-_MBA_Lyon_2014.JPG|thumb|300px]] '''''The Coronation of Inês de Castro in 1361''''' is a c.1849 oil on canvas history painting by the French artist [[Pierre-Charles Comte]], first exhibited at the [[Paris Salon]] of 1849 (his second-ever work exhibited at a Salon) and now in the [[Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]], which it entered in 1885.
Other painters of the time had also painted works on the life of [[Inês de Castro]] - count Auguste de Forbin in 1812 (he also exhibited an autograph copy at the 1819 Salon), [[Gillot Saint-Evre]] in 1827, [[Eugénie Servières]]'s ''Inês de Castro throwing herself and her children at the feet of Alfonso IV of Portugal to free don Pedro, her husband'' (exhibited at the 1824 Salon) and ''Inês de Castro Before Her Murder'' (1839).
==Sources== *http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_1=REF&VALUE_1=000PE025897
{{DEFAULTSORT:Coronation of Ines de Castro in 1361}} [[category:1849 paintings]] [[category:French paintings]] [[category:History paintings]] [[category:Paintings of the Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]] {{19C-painting-stub}}

It premiered on January 2, 2016. The three judges for the inaugural season were [[Tamer Hosny]], [[Nancy Ajram]] and [[Kathem Al-Saher]]. There are four stages starting with the Blind Auditions. Contestants sing without being seen by the judges. If a coach likes the contestant's performance, they turn their chair. Each coach is allowed to have 15 contestants on their team. The season 1 finale was on March 5, 2016 and the winning contestant was Lynn Al-Hayek from Lebanon from Team Kadhem Al-Saher. The season 2 finale was on February 3, 2018, and the winner was Hamza Lebyed from Morocco from Team Kadhem Al-Saher. == ''The Voice Kids'' coaches == * {{flagicon|Iraq}} [[Kazem al-Saher]] - Iraqi composer-musician, singer and poet * {{flagicon|Egypt}} [[Tamer Hosny]] - Egyptian singer, actor, composer, director and songwriter * {{flagicon|Lebanon}} [[Nancy Ajram]] - Lebanese singer ==Series overview== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; font-size:95%;" " width:100%;" |- ! width="20%" | Season ! width="40%" | '''''Season 1'''''
