revision.text:
'''Theater Breaking Through Barriers (TBTB)''', formerly '''[http://tbtb.org/ Theater By the Blind]''', is an [[Inclusion (disability rights)|inclusive]] [[theater company]] in [[New York City]] that strives develop the talents of individuals with disabilities for work onstage, backstage, in the office and in the audience.<ref name="TBTB-intro"/> It was founded in 1979 by Ike Schambelan(who died of cancer in 2015), with sighted actors recording plays for the blind. The theater then moved to performances for the blind and then blind performances for the sighted.<ref name="New York Day by Day: Explaining Blindness"/> They recently began doing a short play festival each year.
==Crystal Clear== ''Crystal Clear'' by [[Phil Young (playwright)|Phil Young]] opened in 1986 at the [[Long Wharf Theater]]'s Stage II. The show starred (George Ashiotis) who played a young actor who is gradually going blind from diabetes and his girlfriend who has been blind from birth (Lucia Puccia) . ''Crystal Clear'' began as an improvisation on a [[London]] pub stage in 1982.
The production had mixed reviews from critics. Mel Gusso said for The New York Times, "It is diagnostic rather than psychologically probing."<ref name="crystal"/> Another critic said the play was "a wildly unfocused work that tries to cover too vast a terrain" and that it contained "a cornucopia of cliches".<ref name="sentimental"/>
==A Midsummer Night's Dream== ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' by [[William Shakespeare]] staged at the Barrow Group Theater in [[Manhattan]], was the first play by TBTB to feature a character in a wheelchair: {{Quote|text=It holds Ann Marie Morelli, an actress playing Hermia, who at first has the attention of one too many men but later finds herself with the attention of one too few. Hermia, as created by Shakespeare, is short, and her rival in love, Helena (Erin O’Leary), is tall. Through the centuries poor Hermia has always taken a verbal beating for her physique, but here it has a different bite.
"Get you gone, you dwarf, you minimus," barks Lysander, who once doted on her. And Hermia herself laments, "My legs can keep no pace with my desires." |sign=Neil Genzlinger<ref name="Actors Who See With More Than Their Eyes"/> |source=New York Times }} A note in the theater program said, "Increasingly we feel we must include all disabled people [rather than blind people only] in our work."<ref name="Actors Who See With More Than Their Eyes"/> To reflect this shift in thought and philosophy, 2008 saw the company changing its name from Theater By The Blind to Theater Breaking Through Barriers.<ref name="Theater by the Blind Changes Name"/> Productions, such as Romeo & Juliet, closely followed featuring an actor, Gregg Mozgala, with Cerebral Palsy, their first in a subsequent line of productions incorporating actors with various disabilities.
==Notes== {{Portal|Theatre|Disability}} <references> <ref name="TBTB-intro">{{Cite web |title=Theater Breaking Through Barriers: An Introduction |url=http://www.tbtb.org/intro.htm |publisher=Theater Breaking Through Barriers |year=2007 <!-- |accessdate=2010-09-26 --> |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101114204154/http://www.tbtb.org/intro.htm |archivedate=2010-11-14 |accessdate=2012-07-18 }}</ref>
<ref name="New York Day by Day: Explaining Blindness">{{Cite web |last1=Heller Anderson |first1=Susan | last2=Dunlap |first2=David W. |date=1985-07-25 |title=New York Day by Day; Explaining Blindness |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/07/25/nyregion/new-york-day-by-day-explaining-blindness.html |work=New York Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6052Z5Gfy |archivedate=2011-07-10 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2011-07-10 }}</ref>
<ref name="crystal">{{Cite web |last=Gusso |first= Mel |date=1986-01-09 |title = Crystal Clear at the Longwarf |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/01/09/theater/theater-crystal-clear-at-the-long-wharf.html |work=New York Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6051rM9Jt |archivedate=2011-07-10 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2011-07-10 }}</ref>
<ref name="sentimental">{{Cite web |last=Klein |first=Alvin |date=1986-01-05 |title=Sentimental Theme Lacking in Impact |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/01/05/nyregion/sentimental-theme-lacking-in-impact.html |work=New York Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/605027GDD |archivedate=2011-07-10 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2011-07-10 }}</ref>
<ref name="Actors Who See With More Than Their Eyes">{{Cite web |last=Genzlinger |first=Neil |date=2007-02-06 |title=Actors Who See With More Than Their Eyes |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B00E3DA133FF935A35751C0A9619C8B63 |work=New York Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/604zjuVuA |archivedate=2011-07-10 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2011-07-10 }}</ref>
<ref name="Theater by the Blind Changes Name">{{Cite web |last=Horwitz |first=Simi |date=2008-01-24 |title=Theater by the Blind Changes Name |url=http://www.backstage.com/bso/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003701648 |work=Back Stage |publisher=Nielsen Business Media |accessdate=2012-07-18 |quote=After 29 years, Theater by the Blind is changing its name to Theater Breaking Through Barriers. The company will continue its commitment to blind and vision-impaired artists, but it has expanded its mission to include performers with a range of disabilities. }}<!-- old url=http://www.backstage.com/bso/news_reviews/nyc/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003701648 accessdate=2010-11-14 --></ref> </references>
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.tbtb.org/}}
[[Category:Theatrical organizations in the United States]] [[Category:Disability theatre]] [[Category:1979 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Culture of New York City]]

[[File:B. Perat, Vernissage au salon, Paris 1866.jpg|thumb|Vernissage, [[Salon (Paris)|Salon (Paris)]], 1866.]]
A '''vernissage''' (from [[French language|French]], originally meaning “[[varnish]]ing”) is a term used for a preview of an [[art exhibition]], which may be private, before the formal [[Grand opening|opening]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/vernissage| title=Vernissage | publisher=[[Merriam-Webster]] | work=Dictionary | year=2010 | accessdate=18 January 2013 }}</ref> If the vernissage is not open to the public, but only for invited guests, it is often called a ''[[private view]]''.
At official exhibitions in the nineteenth century, such as the [[Royal Academy summer exhibition]], artists would give a finishing touch to their works by varnishing them. The custom of patrons and the élite of visiting the academies during the varnishing day prior to the formal opening of the exhibition gave rise to the tradition of celebrating the completion of an art work or a series of art works with friends and sponsors. In the twentieth century it became an opportunity to market the works on view to buyers and critics.
[[File:Finnisage, Berlin, 2003.jpg|thumb|Geheimat Multinational Gallery, Berlin-Charlottenburg – Finissage, 2003.]] [[File:Jonn_Leffmann_-_En_passant_-_vernissagekort_2004.jpg|thumb|222px|Invitation card to a Vernissage.]] There is a comparable ceremonial ending of art exhibitions, called a ''finissage''<ref>{{cite web|title=Invitation: Finissage in Venice|url=http://www.artelagunaprize.com/index.php/speed-news-premio/227-finissage-in-venice.html|accessdate=11 April 2013}}</ref>, from the French word meaning "finishing". Larger art exhibitions may also have an event halfway through their residency called a ''midissage''. These latter terms are rare in English; they are more commonly used in [[German language|German]] but not in French.{{CN|date=August 2014}} The term ''finissage'' was first used in this context in 2003 by Walter Hilliger and Sabine Sallarsaïb for Geheimat Multinational Gallery in Berlin, Germany.
==See also== * [[Private view]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=DMqfAAAAMAAJ Vernissage]: The Magazine of the [[National Gallery of Canada]] * [http://www.vernissage-online.eu/ Vernissage — Die Zeitschrift zur Ausstellung] * [[:de:Finissage_(Veranstaltung)|Finissage]]
{{art-stub}}
[[Category:Art exhibitions]] [[Category:Museum events]]

revision.text:
{{for|the charitable organization set up by NFL quarterback [[Michael Vick]] and his family|Michael Vick}} {{refimprove|date=February 2017}} [[Image:vick_foundation.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Logo]]
The '''Vick Foundation''' was established <ref>[http://www.vickfoundation.com/en/index.html Official site]</ref> in February 2004 to award an annual prize for best [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]] [[novel]]. There is also a competition for the most popular short-listed book, based on votes cast by the general public. In 2008, the award will celebrate its 5th anniversary, and the foundation is on the path to becoming an institution in Bulgaria.
==History== Vick's initiative was acclaimed by those who saw in the prize a new opportunity for the Bulgarian literature after almost 15 years of standstill.
A permanent committee, which includes [[Stefan Danailov]], the current Minister of Culture of [[Bulgaria]], elects а jury. Other members in the committee are Raymond Wagenstein, Boyan Biolchev, Nedyalko Yordanov, Hristo Droumev and Ivan Granitski. The jury changes each year and they select a short list of six Bulgarian novels from which the winner is chosen. One of the member making up the 2008 jury is [[Meglena Kuneva]], the current European commissioner in [[Bulgaria]].
The aim of the foundation is also to enable others to gain access into Bulgarian literature, especially for the literary world beyond Bulgaria.
The award ceremony each year is well attended by members of Bulgarian society and journalist, as can be seen by the [http://www.vickfoundation.com/bg/gallery.html photo gallery on the website]. The event is covered by TV channels in Bulgaria and causes quite a media furor annually. [[KariZa]] and other well-known performers have graced the stages during the award ceremony and the ceremonies are known to be of much entertainment value.
The competition is organised with the support of [[Translation Company EVS]]
==Vick Prize winners== *2004: [http://www.vickfoundation.com/en/winner_2004.html ''Ekzekoutorat''] ([[The Executioner (Kisyov novel)]]) by [[Stefan Kisyov]] *2005: Staklenata reka (The Glass River) by Emil Andreev *2006: ''[[Amazonkata na Varoe]]'' (Varoe's Amazon) by Prof. [[Boyan Biolchev]] *2007: Partien Dom (Party Headquarters) by [[Georgi Tenev]] *2008: Photo Stoyanovich by Evgenia Ivanova
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.vickfoundation.com/en/index.html Official site] *[http://www.evs-translations.com EVS Translations] *[http://www.prevod.evs-translations.com/edward_vick.htm About Edward Vick] *[http://www.sofiaecho.com/article/nominees-for-novel-of-the-year-award-announced/id_30117/catid_70?bulletinstat=1 ''Sofia Echo'' reports on short-listed novels]
[[Category:Bulgarian literary awards]] [[Category:Arts foundations]] [[Category:Organizations based in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2004]] [[Category:Awards established in 2004]]
{{lit-award-stub}}
